title: Newcastle's Gibson Street baths put on the market by council for a second time
text:
Business Newcastle's Gibson Street baths put on the market by council for a second time The historic bath house is on the market again - and that could mean progress for campaigners keen to save it from developers Share Click to play Tap to play The video will start in 8 Cancel Play now Get business   Thank you for subscribing!   
A historic bathouse on the edge of Newcastle city centre is to be put back on the market. 
Newcastle City Council originally announced plans to sell the Gibson Street Baths last April, only to suspend the process when a community campaign was started to save the 100-year-old building. 
The return of the building to the property market gives community groups the chance to buy the building, which is believed to be one of the oldest public bath houses in the UK, but hasn’t been used for swimming since the 1960s and has lain empty for some years. Gibson Street Baths and Wash House in Newcastle which is up for auction 
Campaigners succeeded in getting the building listed as an Asset of Community Value in July, and propose making part of the building into a boutique hotel, cafe and bar which would fund the use of the old swimming pool hall for arts and other community purposes. 
Under the terms of the Localism Act 2011, the council has to give community groups six weeks to express an interest in the building, after which it can freely dispose of the building, giving developers the chance to put in their bids. 
Cabinet member for investment and development, Coun Ged Bell, said: “Gibson Street Baths was one of the earliest public baths in the country and is still a very prominent building. Gibson Street Baths and Wash House in Newcastle which is up for auction 
“Sadly, it’s in a bit of a state, and the council is keen to pass it on to another organisation with the resources to restore it to its former glory – sadly that is not going to be the council with our declining budgets. 
“We are therefore serving notice of our intention to dispose of the property.” 
The building was opened in 1907 and is believed to be among the oldest public bath houses in Britain with the interior laid out as a large swimming pool in a domed glazed-roof hall, along with a former wash house with a domed ceiling. It closed in 1965 as public baths and until recently was being used as a badminton club. The building is now in a state of disrepair but still shows signs of its grand past through ornate tiled panels. 
The property is said to be suited to a variety or mix of uses, such as business, leisure, residential or entertainment. Like us on Facebook
